title: The Letters of Robert Burns
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Iused all my eloquence, all the persuasive flourishes of the hand, andheart-melting modulation of periods in my power, to urge her out toHarvieston, but all in vain.

title: The Letters of Robert Burns
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Afterbreakfast, we made a party to go and see the famous Caudron-linn, aremarkable cascade in the Devon, about five miles above Harvieston; andafter spending one of the most pleasant days I ever had in my life, Ireturned to Stirling in the evening.

title: The Letters of Robert Burns
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Yesterday morning I rode from this town up the meandering Devon's banks,to pay my respects to some Ayrshire folks at Harvieston.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I well remember, that the ladies at Harvieston, who accompanied us on this jaunt, expressed  their disappointment at his not expressing itt more glowing language, his impressions of the Caldron Linn scene, certainly highly sublime, and somewhat horrible.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: " During a residence of about ten days at Harvieston,  we made excursions to visit various parts of the surrounding scenery, inferior to none in Scotland, in beauty, sublimity, and romantic interest ; particularly Castle Campbell, the ancient seat of the family of Argyle  : and the famous Cataract of the Devon ; called the Caldron Linn; and the Rumbling Bridge, a single  broad arch, thrown by the Devil, if tradition is to be believed, across the river, at about the height of a hundred feet above its bed.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.

snippet: [These verses were composed on a charming yourg lady, Charlotte Hamilton, sister to the poet's friend, Gavin Hamilton of MauciiUne, residing, wlicn the song was written, at Harvieston, on the banks of the Devon, in the county of Clackmannan.]
